JUDGES: Alvina Gyulumyan;Corneliu Bîrsan;Egbert Myjer;Ján Šikuta;Josep Casadevall;Luis López Guerra;Nona Tsotsoria
TEXT: CARDINAL . The applicant , Mr PERSON , is a NORP national , who was born in DATE and lives in GPE . He was represented before the ORG by Mr PERSON and Mr PERSON , lawyers practising in GPE . ORG ( “ the Government ” ) were represented by their Agent , Mr PERSON of ORG .
CARDINAL . NORP The facts of the case , as submitted by the parties , may be summarised as follows .

CARDINAL . On DATE a married couple , PERSON and PERSON , lodged a criminal complaint with the police , alleging that they had been victims of kidnapping and extortion . On DATE criminal proceedings were initiated under ORG CARDINAL § CARDINAL ( a ) and ( b ) , CARDINAL § CARDINAL ( a ) and ( b ) and QUANTITY and CARDINAL of LAW of GPE for aggravated unlawful deprivation of liberty , extortion and unlawful purchase and possession of firearms .

CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant was arrested in connection with the above proceedings . As disclosed by the record of a search of the applicant ’s vehicle , which according to the applicant had been falsified , several items of evidence were found in the vehicle and collected for further examination , including one hand grenade , several cartridges and a face mask .

CARDINAL . The applicant alleges that on the same date several police officers subjected him to ill - treatment upon his transfer to ORG of GPE , with the aim of obtaining a confession to the charges against him . The police officers allegedly tied the applicant to a chair and beat him for TIME , the applicant receiving a particularly large number of blows to the head . The beatings were allegedly encouraged and supervised by CARDINAL senior police officers , PERSON . and Mr. PERSON , who threatened to kill the applicant if he did not plead guilty .

CARDINAL . Subsequently , the applicant was transferred to a temporary detention centre , where , upon admission , he was visually examined by a duty officer in the presence of another prison officer . According to the record drawn up by the duty officer and duly signed by the applicant ( “ the record of CARDINAL DATE ” ) , multiple scratches and reddened areas were identified on the applicant ’s neck . The record also stated that the applicant had said that he had sustained those injuries prior to his arrest .
CARDINAL . At a photo identity parade held on DATE , the victims identified the applicant as one of their kidnappers .

CARDINAL . On DATE a department head of ORG , relying on the record of DATE , instructed the NORP - Saburtalo district prosecutor to inquire into the origin of the applicant ’s injuries and take any lawful actions required . As disclosed by the case file , the above request has not resulted in any actual investigative actions .

CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant and CARDINAL co - accused were convicted on multiple charges of aggravated kidnapping , extortion , hostage - taking , unlawful purchase and possession of firearms , and causing both grave and minor bodily injuries , committed while acting in an organised , armed criminal gang . The applicant was sentenced to DATE imprisonment . The applicant ’s conviction was primarily based on the ORG statements , the results of the identity parade , the record of the search of the applicant ’s vehicle , statements from the police officers who had conducted the search , and an analysis of the incoming and outgoing mobile phone calls of the applicant and his CARDINAL co - accused . According to the transcript of the trial hearing , both victims identified the applicant in court as the perpetrator . The court rejected the applicant ’s alibi and supporting witness testimonies as unsubstantiated , reasoning that the alibi had been made up with the sole purpose of evading criminal responsibility .

CARDINAL . In his appeal dated DATE , the applicant reiterated all the arguments made by him at the first - instance hearing . Notably , the applicant challenged the results of the search of his vehicle and complained of inaccurate assessment of evidence by the trial court and also about the dismissal of his alibi . The applicant did not make allegations of ill - treatment .

CARDINAL . On DATE ORG , whilst whilst rejecting CARDINAL of the aggravating circumstances modifying the qualification of the offences , maintained the applicant ’s conviction and his sentence of CARDINAL years’ imprisonment . The appellate court endorsed the reasoning of the first - instance court concerning the conclusiveness of the incriminating evidence . On DATE ORG of GPE rejected the applicant ’s appeal on points of law .

CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant ’s lawyer lodged a criminal complaint with ORG and , relying on LAW , requested the initiation of a criminal investigation of the applicant ’s allegations of ill - treatment . The lawyer denounced the failure of the prosecuting authorities to carry out the prosecutor ’s instructions of CARDINAL September CARDINAL , and to conduct an inquiry into the circumstances in which the applicant had sustained his injuries . The lawyer particularly stressed the relevant authorities’ failure to question the applicant in connection with his injuries . In support of the above request , the lawyer provided ORG with a copy of the record of DATE assessing the applicant ’s injuries , the applicant ’s statement describing ill - treatment he stated he had suffered DATE including the names of some of the alleged perpetrators , and a copy of the prosecutor ’s decision of DATE .
CARDINAL . The above complaint was forwarded to the GPE prosecutor on DATE with a request to report back .

CARDINAL . On DATE criminal proceedings were initiated by the prosecuting authorities in connection with the applicant ’s allegations of ill - treatment on DATE . On DATE , while being questioned as a witness , the applicant maintained his allegations of ill - treatment and named the key suspects again . On DATE a forensic examination established that the applicant ’s injuries as described in the record of CARDINAL September CARDINAL were of a minor nature , causing no damage to his state of health .

CARDINAL . As disclosed by the relevant criminal case file submitted by the Government , several witnesses were questioned , including CARDINAL of the alleged suspects named by the applicant and the CARDINAL investigators and the prosecutor in charge of the criminal case against the applicant . They all denied the applicant ’s allegations . Several other investigative actions were also carried out for the purpose of verifying the applicant ’s claims . According to the Government , no evidence was found to substantiate the applicant ’s allegations .

CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant was transferred to the psychiatric wing of the prison hospital with symptoms of post - traumatic stress disorder . By that time he had developed insomnia , frequent headaches and dizziness . He complained in particular of depression , irritability and tinnitus . Following a psychiatric evaluation , the applicant was diagnosed as suffering from emotionally unstable personality disorder and post - traumatic nonpsychotic cerebral syndrome . The medical report of the applicant ’s treatment in the prison hospital DATE and CARDINAL DATE noted that the applicant had suffered from concussion several times in the past . The report also noted that the applicant had never been registered with any psychiatric hospital in the past and that his parents did not suffer from any genetically transmissible diseases .
CARDINAL . The applicant was discharged from the prison hospital after DATE of treatment and returned to GPE no . CARDINAL Prison on DATE .

CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant ’s lawyer wrote a letter to the governor of GPE no . CARDINAL Prison , where the applicant was an inmate at the material time , inquiring about the availability of a psychiatrist in the prison . In a reply of CARDINAL DATE , the prison governor informed the lawyer that the applicant had been transferred to ORG no . CARDINAL Prison . He further maintained in general terms that a psychiatrist from the prison hospital was asked to attend whenever the need arose .

CARDINAL . In DATE the applicant raised new medical grievances with the prison authorities . Notably , he complained of pain in the waist area and after a medical check - up was diagnosed with radiculopathy . The applicant was prescribed relevant drug - based treatment on an out - patient basis .

CARDINAL . As disclosed by his medical file , the applicant subsequently had periodic consultations with various specialists , including a psychiatrist . The most recent consultation , on DATE , indicated that the applicant ’s mental condition was stable , with no signs of psychosis .
CARDINAL . NORP The relevant provisions of LAW , as in force at the material time , read as follows :
Article CARDINAL – Obligation to initiate a preliminary investigation
“ Upon receipt of information concerning the commission of a crime , the investigator and the public prosecutor , within the limits of their powers , shall open an investigation . ... ”
Article CARDINAL – Information concerning the commission of a crime

“ CARDINAL . A preliminary investigation shall be opened on the basis of information concerning the commission of a crime brought to the attention of the investigator or the public prosecutor by a natural person or other legal entity ... reported in the media , or brought to light during the investigation of a case by the authority in charge of the investigation ... ”
